BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Significant increase in avalanche danger as a consequence of new snow and strong wind.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
A very large quantity of fresh snow and the sometimes large wind slabs that are forming during the snowfall can be released easily or naturally in all aspects above the tree line. Individual large natural avalanches are to be expected, especially in case of releases originating from very steep high-altitude leeward starting zones. The avalanche prone locations are sometimes covered with new snow and are barely recognisable, even to the trained eye. Avalanches can also be triggered in the old snowpack and reach quite a large size in particular on very steep west, north and east facing slopes. Such avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular above approximately 2400 m.

On steep grassy slopes medium-sized gliding avalanches are possible as a consequence of the new snow, especially on sunny slopes below approximately 2400 m.

Backcountry touring and other off-piste activities call for experience in the assessment of avalanche danger and restraint.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Up to 50 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall on Friday above approximately 1500 m. The strong wind will transport the new snow significantly.

Especially shady slopes above approximately 2400 m: The new snow and wind slabs are lying on soft layers.

The old snowpack remains subject to considerable local variations at high altitude. Within the snowpack, there are multiple melt-freeze crusts sandwiches with faceted layers in between, in particular on steep sunny slopes in all altitude zones, as well as on shady slopes below approximately 2600 m.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment:
With the end of the snowfall, the natural activity of slab avalanches will slowly decrease.
More frequent loose snow avalanches are to be expected as the day progresses, in particular medium-sized ones, in the event of solar radiation especially on extremely steep sunny slopes.
The activity of gliding avalanches will increase, in particular on steep east, south and west facing slopes below approximately 2400 m.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The large quantity of fresh snow as well as the often deep wind slabs represent the main danger. Without question, it is inadvisable to engage in backcountry touring.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Increase in avalanche danger as a consequence of new snow and strong wind. In all aspects large and, in many cases, very large avalanches are possible as a consequence of the precipitation.
The new snow and wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant in all aspects. Exposed parts of transportation routes can be endangered in some localities in particular in the regions exposed to heavier precipitation.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: As a consequence of snowfall and the strong southwesterly wind, fresh snow drift accumulations will form. The large quantity of fresh snow as well as the wind slabs that are forming in all aspects are bonding poorly with the old snowpack.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The weather will be cloudy over a wide area.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights:
Increase in avalanche danger as a consequence of new snow and strong wind. This applies in particular in the regions exposed to heavier precipitation.
Without question, it is inadvisable to engage in backcountry touring.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The large quantity of fresh snow as well as the often deep wind slabs represent the main danger. In particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls large and very large avalanches are possible as a consequence of the precipitation.
The new snow and wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant in all aspects.
A lot of rain will fall in some localities.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: As a consequence of snowfall and the strong southwesterly wind, fresh snow drift accumulations will form. The large quantity of fresh snow as well as the wind slabs that are forming in all aspects are bonding poorly with the old snowpack.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The weather will be cloudy over a wide area.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Significant increase in avalanche danger as a consequence of new snow and strong wind.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The large quantity of fresh snow and the sometimes large wind slabs that are forming during the snowfall can be released easily or naturally in all aspects above the tree line. Medium-sized natural avalanches are to be expected, especially in case of releases originating from very steep high-altitude leeward starting zones. The avalanche prone locations are sometimes covered with new snow and are barely recognisable, even to the trained eye. Avalanches can also be triggered in the old snowpack and reach quite a large size in particular on very steep west, north and east facing slopes. Such avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular above approximately 2400 m.

On steep grassy slopes medium-sized gliding avalanches are possible as a consequence of the new snow, especially on sunny slopes below approximately 2400 m.

Backcountry touring and other off-piste activities call for experience in the assessment of avalanche danger and restraint.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Over a wide area 20 to 40 cm of snow will fall on Friday above approximately 1500 m. The strong wind will transport the new snow significantly.

Especially shady slopes above approximately 2400 m: The new snow and wind slabs are lying on soft layers.

The old snowpack remains subject to considerable local variations at high altitude. Within the snowpack, there are multiple melt-freeze crusts sandwiches with faceted layers in between, in particular on steep sunny slopes in all altitude zones, as well as on shady slopes below approximately 2600 m.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment:
With the end of the snowfall, the natural activity of slab avalanches will slowly decrease.
More frequent loose snow avalanches are to be expected as the day progresses, in particular medium-sized ones, in the event of solar radiation especially on extremely steep sunny slopes.
The activity of gliding avalanches will increase, in particular on steep east, south and west facing slopes below approximately 2400 m.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Locally heavy snowfall and strong winds will lead to a significant increase in avalanche danger
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
From today evening, worsening weather with locally heavy snowfall above 1200-1400 m in the Dolomites and above 1500-1700 m in the Pre-Alps. Fresh snowfall expected until Saturday 24 February: Dolomites at 2000 m 35-60 cm; Pre-Alps over 1500 m 50-70 cm. Locally, contributions may be even higher.
New snow will fall on a smooth, hard snowpack surface, and dry loose snow avalanches will be possible at all exposures. Avalanches in some cases can reach even large sizes and locally affect man-made areas.
Avalanches expected in man-made areas may affect sites usually exposed to avalanche danger in a localised manner, and in particular high-altitude communication routes and Dolomite passes.
Winds at high altitudes will be strong and will redistribute the loose snow, creating new deposits of windrift snow.
New snow drifts can be released even with a weak overload (e.g. single skier) and the resulting slab avalanches can also be large.
From Friday, the avalanche danger for the Dolomites and the Pre-Alps is estimated at grade 3.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Fresh snow falls on a generally stable snowpack with a surface-bearing crust at all exposures. On shaded slopes, the snowpack still retains a winter structure, but faceted crystals are rounding off.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: New snow and wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Above approximately 1300 m snow will fall until the early morning. The wind will be strong in some localities in particular along the border with France.
As a consequence of a moderate to strong wind from westerly directions, wind slabs will form especially adjacent to ridgelines and in pass areas. During the night the previously small wind slabs will increase in size additionally.
They can be released easily, even by a single winter sport participant,, especially in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain.
The number and size of avalanche prone locations will increase with altitude. At elevated altitudes the likelihood of avalanches is higher.
Natural avalanches: Dry loose snow avalanches and dry slab avalanches are possible from the first half of the night, in the regions exposed to heavier precipitation especially on very steep slopes.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Thursday: 10 to 15 cm of snow fell in the late morning.
20 to 30 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall until late in the night above approximately 1500 m. The fresh snow as well as the wind slabs are bonding only slowly with the old snowpack in particular on shady slopes.
The old snowpack is favourably layered.
At low altitude only a little snow is lying.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The danger of natural avalanches will decrease gradually.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: New snow and wind slabs: At intermediate and high altitudes a considerable avalanche danger will prevail.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Above approximately 1200 m snow will fall until the afternoon. Over a wide area over a wide area 20 to 25 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen above approximately 2000 m. The wind was moderate in the vicinity of peaks.
The more recent wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant and generally at intermediate and high altitudes. They are to be found especially adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls in all aspects.
In the regions exposed to heavier precipitation and at intermediate and high altitudes the avalanche danger will increase rapidly to level 3 (considerable).
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Wind and new snow above approximately 1200 m. 20 cm of snow fell on Thursday above approximately 2000 m. The sometimes strong wind has transported the new snow significantly. In some places new snow and wind slabs are lying on a hard crust. The old snowpack will be generally stable.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Significant increase in avalanche danger as a consequence of new snow and strong wind.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The large quantity of fresh snow and the sometimes large wind slabs that are forming during the snowfall can be released easily or naturally in all aspects at intermediate and high altitudes. Medium-sized natural avalanches are to be expected, especially in case of releases originating from very steep leeward starting zones. The avalanche prone locations are covered with new snow and are barely recognisable, even to the trained eye. Avalanches can also be triggered in the old snowpack and reach quite a large size in particular on very steep west, north and east facing slopes.
On steep grassy slopes medium-sized gliding avalanches are possible as a consequence of the new snow.
Backcountry touring and other off-piste activities call for extensive experience in the assessment of avalanche danger and great restraint.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Over a wide area 30 to 60 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall on Friday above approximately 1500 m. The strong wind will transport the new snow.
The new snow and wind slabs are lying on a crust in all aspects below approximately 2400 m. Especially shady slopes above approximately 2400 m: The new snow and wind slabs are bonding poorly with the old snowpack in all aspects.
The old snowpack remains subject to considerable local variations at high altitude.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment:
Numerous loose snow avalanches are to be expected as the day progresses, but they can be quite large, in the regions exposed to a lot of new snow especially on very steep slopes.
The natural activity of slab avalanches will slowly decrease.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The new snow and wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Above approximately 1500 m snow will fall until the afternoon. In these regions the avalanche danger will increase gradually to level 2 (moderate).
The fresh snow of the last two days and in particular the mostly small wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant, in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in pass areas in particular at high altitudes and in high Alpine regions. In the regions exposed to heavier precipitation caution is to be exercised in particular on steep slopes.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Over a wide area new snow and wind slabs are lying on a hard crust.
Large-grained weak layers exist in the snowpack in particular on shady slopes. This applies especially on shady slopes. The old snowpack remains generally stable.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Gradual increase in avalanche danger as a consequence of the snowfall.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The fresh snow as well as the sometimes large wind slabs that are forming above all adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls can be released easily, or, in isolated cases naturally above approximately 1800 m. As a consequence of the snowfall, the likelihood of ground avalanches being released will increase gradually in particular on steep southeast and southwest facing slopes at intermediate altitudes. The soft wind slabs must be evaluated with care and prudence above approximately 2000 m.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Sunshine and high temperatures will give rise from the middle of the day to increasing moistening of the snowpack in particular on steep sunny slopes above approximately 1600 m.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Gradual increase in avalanche danger as a consequence of the snowfall.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The fresh snow as well as the sometimes large wind slabs that are forming above all adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls can be released easily, or, in isolated cases naturally above approximately 1800 m. As a consequence of the snowfall, the likelihood of ground avalanches being released will increase gradually in particular on steep southeast and southwest facing slopes at intermediate altitudes. The soft wind slabs must be evaluated with care and prudence above approximately 2000 m.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Sunshine and high temperatures will give rise from the middle of the day to increasing moistening of the snowpack in particular on steep sunny slopes above approximately 1600 m.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: As a consequence of new snow and wind the prevalence and size of the avalanche prone locations will increase as the day progresses.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Above approximately 1300 m snow will fall until the early morning. As a consequence of a moderate wind from westerly directions, mostly small wind slabs will form during the second half of the night especially adjacent to ridgelines and in pass areas.
The fresh snow as well as the wind slabs represent the main danger. They can be released.
The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular on very steep slopes and in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain.
The number and size of avalanche prone locations will increase with altitude.
Natural avalanches: Dry avalanches are possible, but they will be mostly small, especially on extremely steep slopes.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
10 to 20 cm of snow will fall until the early morning above approximately 1500 m.
The fresh snow as well as the wind slabs are bonding only slowly with the old snowpack in particular on shady slopes.
The old snowpack is favourably layered.
At low and intermediate altitudes only a little snow is lying.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The danger of natural avalanches will decrease gradually.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: In the regions exposed to heavier precipitation above approximately 2100 m danger level 2 (moderate) will be reached.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Above approximately 1500 m snow will fall until the afternoon.
The fresh snow of the last two days and in particular the mostly small wind slabs can be released in isolated cases, in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in pass areas in particular at high altitudes and in high Alpine regions. In the regions exposed to heavier precipitation this applies in particular on very steep slopes.
Apart from the danger of being buried, restraint should be exercised as well in view of the danger of avalanches sweeping people along and giving rise to falls.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
The new snow will be deposited on bare ground over a wide area.
In some places new snow and wind slabs are lying on a hard crust. This applies in particular on shady slopes and at high altitudes and in high Alpine regions.
The old snowpack remains generally stable.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: New snow and wind slabs at intermediate and high altitudes.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
In particular along the border with France some new snow to intermediate altitudes. The mostly small wind slabs can be released in some cases in particular on very steep shady slopes above approximately 2300 m. This applies in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in pass areas in particular at high altitudes and in high Alpine regions.
Apart from the danger of being buried, restraint should be exercised as well in view of the danger of avalanches sweeping people along and giving rise to falls.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
The new snow will be deposited on bare ground over a wide area. This applies in particular on sunny slopes, as well as at low and intermediate altitudes.
In some places new snow and wind slabs are lying on a hard crust.
The old snowpack remains generally stable.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Weakly bonded old snow is to be evaluated with care and prudence.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: Individual mostly small avalanches are possible above approximately 1800 m. This applies especially in gullies and bowls.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The old snowpack remains subject to considerable local variations. At high altitude only a little snow is lying. At high altitude mostly small wind slabs formed. In gullies and bowls the wind slabs are larger.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Individual avalanche prone locations are to be found at high altitudes and in high Alpine regions and on very steep slopes.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Above approximately 1500 m snow will fall until late in the night.
As a consequence of a light to moderate wind from westerly directions, small wind slabs will form from the second half of the night.
These can in isolated cases be released by people.
The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular on very steep slopes.
Restraint should be exercised because avalanches can sweep people along and give rise to falls.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
5 to 15 cm of snow will fall until late in the night above approximately 1500 m.
The old snowpack will be in most cases well bonded.
Snow depths vary greatly at high altitudes and in high Alpine regions, depending on the infuence of the wind.
At low and intermediate altitudes only a little snow is lying.
